elements: An occasionally coherent catalogue of the secret gods. This is an English translation of a volume dealing with the powers of the Wood.
An occasionally coherent catalogue of the secret gods. This is an English translation of a volume describing the enmity between the Lionsmith and the Tribune of Scars.
The annotated dream-journals of Christopher Illopoly, sometimes called 'the only readable occultist'.
The annotated dream-journals of Christopher Illopoly, sometimes called 'the only readable occultist'. This is the second volume.
The annotated dream-journals of Christopher Illopoly, sometimes called 'the only readable occultist'. This is the third volume.
Warnings and confessions about the cost of the secret arts, addressed to a student by the seventeenth-century magus (and reputed immortal) Julian Coseley.
The Locksmith's Dream: a Light through the Keyhole
The first volume of Teresa Galmier's examination of parallels in the mystic dreams of artisans.
The Locksmith's Dream: Portions and Proportions
The second volume of Teresa Galmier's examination of parallels in the mystic dreams of artisans. The frontispiece has been slashed with a razor.
The third volume of Teresa Galmier's examination of parallels in the mystic dreams of artisans.
Samuel Savage's satirical comedy, on the intrigues of the ailing, but cunning John Sonne, his mistress Maevelin, her lover Leo, and the upstart Corvino.
Erratic accounts, by one 'Arun', of the hunting and consumption of supposed immortals, by shadowy cults of assassins. Published in the late nineteenth century.
The seventeenth-century mystic and antiquarian Claude Hersault describes divergent incidents in five major Histories.
Herein, the seventeenth-century mystic and antiquarian Claude Hersault describes the 'Bounds' or 'Underplaces' on the borders of dream. He warns that they shift over time.
Solomon Husher writes, perhaps allegorically, of Winter, and its long slow doomed romance with the Sun. The epigraph is 'Sunset at Noon'.
The War of the Roads, 1450-1580, CENSORED EDITION

Willis-Ford describes the War of the Roads, an event in a History other than our own, in detail. But numerous pages have been removed; the name of the publisher is blacked out; and an ominous slip stapled to the cover explains that Willis-Ford has been 'excised'.
A surreal contemporary play by the enigmatic Monica Medina, in which the Queens of the Rivers are murdered, one by one.
The libretto of a lost opera concerning the contest between Apollo and Marsyas, and its tragic outcome. The librettist is identified only by their initials: RKNJL.
Poems of greedy delight composed by the possibly pseudonymous Arabella Dusk, the rumoured heiress-turned-madam-turned-poetess.
The Burning of the Unburnt God
Compiled by Jay Wigglesworth Jensen from oral traditions in rural Persia.
An eighteenth-century epic poem by the pseudonymous 'Solipsistos'.
On What Is Contained By Silver
A dire bestiary of the horrors to be found in mirrors. This is a recent edition of a third century text by 'Poemander'.
A True and Complete Accounting of the Asclepian Mysteries of the Roots of the House

Descriptions of the 'Asclepian Mysteries', reproduced by one 'Rylee Grese' from - supposedly - a much older text. It's unlikely to be genuine, but it makes a reference to 'The House without Walls and its Wood', right there in the prologue.

A fragile manuscript, illuminated with twinned shapes of sad and luminous beauty, and with all the phases of the moon. It might be as old as the seventh century, but the language - Fucine - is much older. Coral decorates its cover, and its page-edges are sharp enough to slash a throat. [I have made notes towards a translation. Now I can study it.]

A fragile manuscript, illuminated with twinned shapes of sad and luminous beauty, and with all the phases of the moon. Coral decorates its cover, and its page-edges are sharp enough to slash a throat. [I've learnt everything I can from this, but the book itself still has power.]
The Orchid Transfigurations, Vol 1: a Feast
The first volume of a compilation of quasi-Rosicrucian allegories, supposedly by Robert Fludd. This is a later English translation.
The Orchid Transfigurations, Vol 2: a Birth
The second volume of a compilation of quasi-Rosicrucian allegories, supposedly by Robert Fludd. This is a later English translation.
The third volume of a compilation of quasi-Rosicrucian allegories, supposedly by Robert Fludd. This is a later English translation.

Subtitled 'Stories from Behind the Walls': a miscellany of non-traditional histories compiled by William Gore, including battles not generally acknowledged and countries which appear on no map, told in a playful, apparently fictional manner.
